articles.headline: Auto Sales for March Offer Hope
articles.snippet: New-vehicle sales fell in March for a 17th consecutive month, but carmakers said proposed federal incentives could mean the market was bottoming out.
articles.abstract: New-vehicle sales fell in March for a 17th consecutive month, but carmakers said proposed federal incentives could mean the market was bottoming out.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — New-vehicle sales fell in March for a 17th consecutive month, but carmakers said that proposed federal incentives and reports from dealers of increased sales in the last week of the month could mean the market was bottoming out.

articles.headline: Reminders From Out of the Blue
articles.snippet: An improved personal reminder system collects your every utterance and idea and holds them for posterity.
articles.abstract: An improved personal reminder system collects your every utterance and idea and holds them for posterity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Positive economic news! Get your positive economic news here!

articles.headline: Skills to Learn, to Restart Earnings
articles.snippet: Finding their retirement nest eggs short, many are doing whatever it takes to start a second career.
articles.abstract: Finding their retirement nest eggs short, many are doing whatever it takes to start a second career.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUSTIN WILLIAMS worked as an engineer at Honeywell International for 31 years, and when he retired last April, he knew he could not afford to stop working. His home in suburban Maryland, on which he had spent his 401(k) savings, was losing value, and his pension did not replace enough of his former income.

articles.headline: China Vies to Be World’s Leader in Electric Cars
articles.snippet: In a new threat to Detroit, China is investing heavily in hybrid and electric-vehicle technology.
articles.abstract: In a new threat to Detroit, China is investing heavily in hybrid and electric-vehicle technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIANJIN, China  Chinese leaders have adopted a plan aimed at turning the country into one of the leading producers of hybrid and all-electric vehicles within three years, and making it the world leader in electric cars and buses after that.

articles.headline: A Quest for a Home, Put on Hold
articles.snippet: Her next move was supposed to be her last, but her well-laid plans to enter a retirement community have been frustrated by the sagging market.
articles.abstract: Her next move was supposed to be her last, but her well-laid plans to enter a retirement community have been frustrated by the sagging market.

articles.headline: Politics Add to Economic Turmoil in Hungary
articles.snippet: The struggle of Hungary’s largest bank, OTP, mirrors that of the nation, whose prime minister unexpectedly resigned.
articles.abstract: The struggle of Hungary’s largest bank, OTP, mirrors that of the nation, whose prime minister unexpectedly resigned.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — The streets of London seethed with protests as the Group of 20 nations met, but this capital was arguably more unsettled.

articles.headline: Light and Cheap, Netbooks Are Poised to Reshape PC Industry
articles.snippet: The personal computer world may be headed for an upheaval as thin and cheap netbooks offer the portability of a cellphone and the power of a PC.
articles.abstract: The personal computer world may be headed for an upheaval as thin and cheap netbooks offer the portability of a cellphone and the power of a PC.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Get ready for the next stage in the personal computer revolution: ultrathin and dirt cheap.
articles.byline: By Ashlee Vance and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: Downturn Puts New Stresses on Libraries
articles.snippet: Anxious, depressed patrons who have nowhere else to go are turning some libraries into emotional hotbeds.
articles.abstract: Anxious, depressed patrons who have nowhere else to go are turning some libraries into emotional hotbeds.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill.  The public library here had just closed its doors one evening in December when two homeless men who had been using the stacks as shelter from the cold got into a fight on the outside steps.
articles.byline: By Susan Saulny and Karen Ann Cullotta

articles.headline: Health Critic Brings a Past and a Wallet
articles.snippet: Some conservatives think Richard L. Scott, who in 1997 was ousted from Columbia/HCA, isn’t an ideal spokesman.
articles.abstract: Some conservatives think Richard L. Scott, who in 1997 was ousted from Columbia/HCA, isn’t an ideal spokesman.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Richard L. Scott is unusual in these tough economic times: a rich, conservative investor willing to spend freely on a political cause.

articles.headline: World Leaders Pledge $1.1 Trillion for Crisis
articles.snippet: President Obama conceded that there were “no guarantees” that the measures proposed by the Group of 20 would reverse the global downturn.
articles.abstract: President Obama conceded that there were “no guarantees” that the measures proposed by the Group of 20 would reverse the global downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  Struggling to bridge deep divides over how to revive a paralyzed global economy, the leaders of the world’s largest economies agreed Thursday to bail out developing countries, stimulate world trade and regulate financial firms more stringently. But President Obama conceded that there were “no guarantees” that those measures would reverse the biggest global downturn in six decades.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Banks Get New Leeway in Valuing Their Assets
articles.snippet: The action by the Financial Accounting Standards Board will probably allow banks to report higher profits; critics said the board buckled under political pressure.
articles.abstract: The action by the Financial Accounting Standards Board will probably allow banks to report higher profits; critics said the board buckled under political pressure.
articles.lead_paragraph: A once-obscure accounting rule that infuriated banks, who blamed it for worsening the financial crisis, was changed Thursday to give banks more discretion in reporting the value of mortgage securities.
